entry.title: Re: Leveraging ADBC for High-Performance HANA Operations in ABAP
entry.content:
ADBC is available since ABAP 6.10 (not 7.40) and documented since 7.02.

ADBC is not limited to HANA.

ABAP SQL (new name of Open SQL) may be used instead of ADBC for using a secondary database and for executing HANA-optimized SQL or procedures.

ADBC can be used for direct access to any database, for using the database features which are not available via ABAP SQL.

ABAP 7.58 Documentation: ADBC

NB: ADBC is obsolete in ABAP 9.16, I guess that it's for the Cloud and the programming is via a Cloud service? (no idea why then ABAP 8.16 introduces a new AMDP feature...)

entry.title: Legal Change - IDIS scenario support through Extensibility in DRC Türkiye
entry.content:
This blog post provides a step-by-step guide on how to implement the new legal requirement released by GIB (GELİR İDARESİ BAŞKANLIĞI) for eInvoice and eDespatch under the Construction Rebar Tracking System (IDIS) using Developer Extensibility for Document and Reporting Compliance Türkiye in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Background:
We have already published a blog titled Developer Extensibility for Document and Reporting Compliance Türkiye in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud which explains how SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud customers can leverage developer extensibility to modify the content of XML files generated during electronic invoice submissions, in accordance with specific business and legal requirements.

Note for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and ECC environments:
In SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and SAP ECC environments, the same extensibility approach is available. However, in these systems, the BAdI implementation must be carried out for EDOC_ADAPTOR instead of EDOC_ADAPTOR_CLOUD.

What’s New?
GIB has published a legal requirement for invoices issued under the Construction Rebar Tracking System, which impacts certain companies starting from 21st November 2025. In this blog, we aim to address this requirement by building on the learnings from the previous blog highlighted in the background.

What are the technical specifications of the requirement?
Currently, the system does not automatically determine whether a billing or finance document is related to the Construction Rebar Tracking  System. Customers must explicitly indicate that the invoice belongs to a Construction Rebar Tracking System and provide the required values.
As part of the legal requirements published by the authorities, the following new Profile IDs must be used in the UBL (Universal Business Language, an ISO standard XML) representation:

  1. IDIS - for eInvoice Scenarios
  2. IDISIRSALIYE – for eDespatch scenarios

eInvoice

  • ProfileID for IDIS Scenario
    For IDIS-relevant invoices, the ProfileID in the UBL-TR XML will be set to IDIS.
    • Cardinality: 1 (Mandatory)
    • This value determines that the invoice belongs to the IDIS scenario
    • The solution will automatically populate this value for applicable

  • Shipment Number (Sevkiyat Numarası) at Header Level:
    • Mapped to: Invoice/AccountingSupplierParty/Party/PartyIdentification
      SE-<number> with schemeID as SEVKIYATINO – This would carry the shipment number prefixed with SE. The total number of characters is 10.
      Example: SE-1345840
    • IssueDate should be filled with the investment certificate date in DD/MM/YYYY format

  • Tag Number (Etiket Numarası) at Item Level:
    • Invoice/InvoiceLine/Item/AdditionalItemIdentification/ID should be filled with tag number generated within the scope of IDIS (Rebar Monitoring System). This number is a 9-character alphanumeric value, where the first 2 characters are letters followed by 7 numeric digits. 
      SchemeID should be ETIKETNO.
      Example: CV0152457

eDespatch

  • ProfileID for IDISIRSALIYE Scenario
    For IDISIRSALIYE-relevant invoices, the ProfileID in the UBL-TR XML will be set to IDISIRSALIYE.
    • Cardinality: 1 (Mandatory)
    • This value determines that the invoice belongs to the IDISIRSALIYE scenario
    • The solution will automatically populate this value for applicable

  • Shipment Number (Sevkiyat Numarası) at Header Level:
    • Mapped to: /DespatchAdvice/DespatchSupplierParty/Party/PartyIdentification
      SE-<number> with schemeID as SEVKIYATINO – This would carry the shipment number prefixed with SE. The total number of characters is 10.
      Example: SE-1345840
    • IssueDate should be filled with the investment certificate date in DD/MM/YYYY format

  • Tag Number (Etiket Numarası) at Item Level:
    • /DespatchAdvice/DespatchLine/Item/AdditionalItemIdentification/ID should be filled with tag number generated within the scope of IDIS (Rebar Monitoring System). This number is a 9-character alphanumeric value, where the first 2 characters are letters followed by 7 numeric digits. 
      SchemeID should be ETIKETNO.
      Example: CV0152457

Result:
When you display the XML file of the electronic document in the eDocument Cockpit (EDOC_COCKPIT) corresponding to the above invoicing scenario, you will see that the mentioned tags are populated accordingly. Please note that any error handling and troubleshooting will depend on the actual submission of this document to the authorized service provider.

Conclusion:
With recent enhancements to the Türkiye Document and Reporting Compliance solution, SAP has made it significantly easier to tailor electronic document outputs.
This improvement gives you more flexibility and helps ensure compliance with Türkiye’s legal requirements.

entry.title: Time Management: purely rule-based for Non-Working Day in Work Schedule without adjusting WS
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

Do you know if below customer request can be executed with the current system status of SAP SF? They do not want to use the Change Work Schedule Temporary.

We would like to implement the special handling for December 24th (Christmas Eve) and December 31st (New Year’s Eve) purely rule-based within Time Management, without any changes to work schedules or time recording variants.

December 24th (Christmas Eve)

  • Not a public holiday

  • Should be treated as a non-working day

  • No vacation day deduction

  • No impact on work schedules

  • To be implemented systemically, e.g. via:

    • a dedicated absence type (e.g. “Christmas Eve – company day off”)

    • in combination with a Business Rule

December 31st (New Year’s Eve)

  • Not a public holiday

  • Remains a regular working day according to the work schedule

  • Automatic deduction of one full vacation day, but only if:

    • the employee is scheduled to work on that day according to their work schedule

  • No vacation deduction for employees who are scheduled to be off on that day

  • The deducted vacation day must not be deletable by the employee

Key Advantages of This Approach

  • No changes required to:

    • work schedules

    • time recording variants

  • Logic is:

    • transparent

    • traceable

    • auditable

  • The solution is:

    • stable for future years

    • independent of annual manual adjustments or special measures

Goal:
A sustainable, rule-based Time Management solution that consistently applies the company-specific handling of December 24th and December 31st across all years.

Thank you and best 

Thiphawan

entry.title: What’s New in SAP Automation Pilot H2 2025
entry.content:
Happy New Year! 🎉

As we kick off 2026, we’re excited to share the latest updates and enhancements in SAP Automation Pilot from the past six months. SAP Automation Pilot has made significant progress in how customers design, run, and monitor automations across complex landscapes. With deeper agent integration, hybrid connectivity, faster execution handling, and closer alignment with SAP Cloud ALM, teams can now automate and observe their processes with greater scale, transparency, and reliability.

 Let’s take a look at the most important innovations.

Enabling AI-Driven and Agent-Based Automation

No-Code MCP Servers Powered by SAP Automation Pilot

SAP Automation Pilot now allows you to create Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers using no-code and low-code tools. These MCP servers expose SAP Automation Pilot commands and workflows as tools that can be consumed by AI agents, including those built with Joule Studio.

This makes it possible for agents to securely trigger automations, retrieve system state, and perform remediation actions using governed SAP Automation Pilot capabilities, instead of relying on ad-hoc scripts or unsecured endpoints.

📘Learn more:

  • Integrating SAP Automation Pilot with AI Agents 
  • Agent builder in Joule Studio is now generally available: Build your own Joule agents today!

Extending Automation into Hybrid Landscapes

SAP Cloud Connector Integration

SAP Automation Pilot can now connect to on-premise systems through SAP Cloud Connector, using existing secure tunnels. This enables automations to reach systems behind corporate firewalls, including SAP and non-SAP solutions, without exposing them to the public internet.

With this integration, customers can automate end-to-end processes that span SAP BTP, SAP S/4HANA or SAP ECC on-premise systems, and internal tools within one consistent automation environment.

The following commands support network calls via SAP Cloud Connector:

📘Learn more: See the documentation on integrating SAP Cloud Connector with SAP Automation Pilot. 

📖Customer story:  Read the success story on how Sierra Digital used the SAP Cloud Connector integration with SAP Automation Pilot.

Faster and More Scalable Execution Monitoring

Enhanced Recent Executions API

The backend API that powers the Recent Executions view has been enhanced with:

  • An increased retention of 5,000 executions (up from 1,000)
  • Server-side filtering to reduce payload size and improve responsiveness

This results in faster UI loading, lower network usage, and better support for high-volume production environments.

📘Learn more: See the Recent Executions API documentation in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Executions Table Redesign

The Executions table has been fully redesigned for performance, usability, and consistency with SAP Fiori guidelines. Rendering time and interaction performance have been improved, and the layout is now more streamlined and easier to navigate.

Filtering is now handled on the backend and supports multi-selection. Users can also clear all filters at once or generate shareable filter URLs. Execution rows include progress bars, SAP Fiori object status indicators with progress messages, tags, and elapsed time. Non-essential columns have been removed, and common actions such as copying IDs, copying URLs, or deleting executions are now available directly from the row.

Together, these changes provide a much more efficient way to monitor and analyze large numbers of executions.

Running Automations in Parallel at Scale

Native Parallel Executions

Parallel execution has been rebuilt and is now implemented directly in SAP Automation Pilot. It no longer requires service account credentials and offers significantly better performance.

Parent and child executions are automatically linked, making it easy to navigate between them in the UI. Tags provide additional traceability, and a Smart View helps configure child execution parameters. Import and export workflows now better support custom user inputs.

New commands are available to programmatically control parallel executions:

  • utils-sapcp:TriggerExecution:1
  • utils-sapcp:GetExecutionStatus:1
  • utils-sapcp:AwaitExecution:1
  • utils-sapcp:GetExecutionOutput:1

These capabilities enable customers to orchestrate large-scale, distributed automation scenarios with full visibility and control.

Faster Automation Creation and Better Troubleshooting

Smart Search for Commands and Inputs

Smart Search now uses GenAI to let users find commands and inputs using natural language. You can describe what you want to do, and SAP Automation Pilot returns the most relevant commands—across both SAP-delivered and custom commands, as long as they are properly tagged.

The feature is available to users enabled for GenAI, improving discoverability and speeding up automation building.

Dynamic Expression Playground

The Expression Playground in SAP Automation Pilot provides a dedicated environment to test, design, and debug dynamic expressions before using them in commands.  You can work with sample data to check your transformations and logic before running an execution. The Expression Generation Assistant can also create expressions from natural language prompts, which you can review and adjust before use.

📘Learn more: See the Dynamic Expression Playground documentation.

Integrating Automation with SAP Cloud ALM

Security Recommendations

SAP Automation Pilot now reports security-relevant information directly to SAP Cloud ALM, including:

  • Expired Basic Authentication service account credentials
  • Use of Basic Authentication

These signals are displayed in the SAP Cloud ALM Run dashboard, enabling earlier detection of risks, better compliance, and faster remediation.

📘 Learn more: See the Monitoring with SAP Cloud ALM documentation.

Customer Telemetry to SAP Cloud ALM Health Monitoring

SAP Automation Pilot can also push custom operational metrics to SAP Cloud ALM Health Monitoring. Customers can use this to visualize automation-related KPIs alongside system health data.

📖 For example, see the scenario that shows how to monitor Cloud Connector connection status and report it to SAP Cloud ALM.

Extending Automation with PowerShell

PowerShell Script Execution

SAP Automation Pilot now supports PowerShell 7.2 via the ExecutePowerShellScript command in the scripts-sapcp catalog. 

📘 Learn more: See the Script Operations (scripts-sapcp) documentation.

Improved Reliability and Diagnostics

Increased HTTP and SQL Timeouts

Timeouts for HTTP and SQL commands have been increased by 9x times, making it possible to handle long-running APIs and resource-intensive database operations more reliably.

Enhanced HTTP Error Messages

HTTP error messages now include response bodies for 3xx, 4xx, and 5xx responses, as well as key standard headers. This provides much richer diagnostic information when API calls fail. A new input parameter allows reverting to the previous error format if required.

Quality-of-Life Improvements

Several smaller but impactful enhancements were also delivered:

  • New JQ function – reduce – for more powerful and concise JSON transformations in dynamic expressions.
  • Input/Output Values Dialog Improvements – added prettify JSON, download input/output, and copy to clipboard functionality for easier inspection and sharing.
  • Execution Status Change events now include the executor path (the exact step where the status changed) and the previously reported status, improving traceability and event-driven integrations.
  • Expanded regional availability: SAP Automation Pilot is now available in 11 SAP BTP regions, improving latency, resilience, and data-residency options.
  • New Common Domain – *.autopilot.cloud.sap – aligns with SAP cloud standards. The legacy domain is still supported, but migration is strongly encouraged. Check the documentation for more details. 

How to stay tuned to recent and upcoming innovations? 

  • What’s New in SAP Automation Pilot
  • SAP Road Map Explorer for SAP Automation Pilot.
  • Release Navigator for SAP Automation Pilot - helping you easily find product release notes, blog posts, and related web pages.
  • Public GitHub SAP Automation Pilot sample use cases;

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: Writing Between Silence and Experience
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

My name is Hakan. I’m a husband and a father, and my two girls are my greatest inspiration in life. I work as an Expert in SAP HANA Solution Support, and today I’d like to share a bit about my hobby as part of the SAP Community Hobbies series. Alongside the technical world, one constant has stayed with me since my youth: writing. Writing is not a project for me, but a state of mind. It’s the moment when experiences, thoughts, and encounters begin to take shape, whether they come from everyday life or from situations far outside the comfort zone.
 

Taking a moment to enjoy the view over Lake Lünersee after a long glacier climb.

Over the years, writing has become the place where movement turns into reflection, intensity into clarity, and silence into meaning.
 
 
A quiet moment in the Mongolian landscape, letting distance and silence speak.
 

How and when did you start this hobby? What sparked your interest?
I started writing very early, long before my notes turned into books. Even as a teenager, I wanted to capture what life does to me, traveling, people, nature, silence, and also the intense or challenging moments. I lived a fast and intense life: mountains, horses, archery, film and stunt projects, traveling through remote regions, motorcycling, martial arts, and even periods where I spent time forging metal and making knives. 


Forging metal taught me focus, patience, and respect for the process.



These were moments that demanded absolute focus. For a period of time, I even lived as a monk, an experience that taught me the value of silence and observation. All of this leaves traces. Writing became the place where I could sort those impressions and give them meaning.
 
 
What do you love most about your hobby?
Writing connects the outer world with the inner one. It is also a form of relaxation for me, a mental reset. When I stand on a mountain or ride my motorcycle, that’s when the clearest thoughts come. In challenging situations, my mind switches into deep concentration, and those moments often become the source of later inspiration. Writing shows me what a moment truly meant and preserves something that would otherwise fade.
 

In the Alps, moving through terrain that demands focus and trust.
 
 
What challenges have you faced, and how did you overcome them?
The biggest challenge is honesty, not toward others, but toward yourself. Writing confronts you with topics you may not immediately have words for. And then there is perfectionism: the belief that something must be “perfect” before you share it. I learned that authenticity matters more than perfection. Sometimes an unfinished thought touches more deeply than a polished one.
 
 
What has been your proudest moment or most meaningful experience?
Several readers told me that my writing expressed feelings they had carried for years but couldn’t articulate. Some said they had to pause because the words were emotionally overwhelming. Knowing that something I first wrote only for myself could give someone else comfort or clarity is incredibly meaningful to me.
 

Balance, patience, elevation.
 
 
What tools or resources would you recommend to beginners?
A pen. A digital document. A quiet moment. You don’t need more than that. Technology plays only a small role. What matters is interest, openness, and the willingness to reflect. In both writing and coaching, the approach is less about technique and more about mindset.
 
 
What tips would you give someone who wants to start?
Don’t wait until you feel ready. Perfection is the biggest enemy of beginning. Write for yourself, not for others. Curiosity is the driving force behind everything, writing, learning, and being human. And remember: your experiences are your greatest raw material. Take them seriously.
 
 
This is where thoughts settle, after the climb.
 
 
How do you continue learning and developing in your hobby?
I learn by experiencing. I travel, observe, listen, try new things, and actively seek new impressions. Whether in workshops, in nature, in conversations, or on the road, every moment contains the potential to learn something. Writing helps me make sense of those experiences. Coaching complements this because it teaches me to listen more deeply, to perceive more subtly, and to shift perspectives. Together, these practices give me a level of clarity I didn’t have before.
 
 
Are there any misconceptions about your hobby that you’d like to correct?
Many people think writing is a special talent. For me, it is more about attention and courage. And coaching is often mistaken for consulting. Coaching is not about giving answers, it’s about accompanying people so they can find their own. Both require presence, not perfection.
 
 
Where can people learn more about this hobby?
Books, podcasts, and communities are great places to start, but the best learning happens when you begin writing yourself. Five minutes a day can open a door.
 

A moment of trust.
 
 
How do you see the connection between your hobby and the SAP world?
In my work in Support, two things are constant: complexity and humanity. Writing and coaching help me connect both.
Writing sharpens clarity and expression. Coaching sharpens perception and understanding. Together, they improve how I communicate with customers and colleagues, how I assess situations, and how I share knowledge, whether in KBAs, conversations, or team coaching sessions. At the end of the day, behind every technical challenge stands a person with a concern. And that’s exactly where my two worlds meet.
 
Coming up next 
I’m happy to pass the baton to @Sumaiya, the next member of our SAP Community, who will share her hobby of home gardening and what inspires her beyond work.

Looking forward to discovering many more stories in this series.

Best regards,
Hakan

entry.title: Styling your Custom Frontend like SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2
entry.content:
🎨 Want to create a custom frontend that perfectly mirrors SAP Sales and Service Cloud Version 2?

When building side-by-side extensions embedded via Mashups, users expect a seamless experience – one that feels native to the standard UI, not like a foreign add-on.

✨I've created a sample application that makes this effortless! It includes ready-to-use CSS styles and design patterns that help you craft custom frontends that look and feel indistinguishable from the standard SSv2 interface.

🚀 The result? Your extensions blend perfectly into the user's workflow, maintaining consistency, usability, and that familiar SAP experience users trust.

tl;dr:  --> Styling your Custom Frontend (Video | Github | Styleguide (html + css on git))

Before diving into my sample and my custom css let's talk about existing UI frameworks. You can get already very close by using the official libraries from SAP and there are several official options:

  • Using the official UI5 Framework
  • Using the UI5 web components for Angular, Vue, React and Svelte
  • Using the Fundamentals Library (Agnostic Styles or Libraries for Angular)

All those three have a lot of added values and are highly recommended. Recently I discussed often that especially for small extensions the UI5 Framework is to heavy and it is better to go for a more native approach. This would lead to the UI5 web components if you want to have it very standardized and to the Fundamentals library if you want it more custom / native. For my sample here I personally chose as underlying framework Vue over Angular because it is more lightweight and for my single page application with a monorepo it just seemed more suitable than a full blown Angular application. So the above options are very good options to have a maintained UI foundation for your custom frontend.

But as we know in some nuances the UX of SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2 follows a more fresh and modern look and some web components used in our Cloud Native application are just unique. And if you really want to do a fully custom app, it might be useful to only style your application with CSS but build it as you want. Exactly for this use case I put some CSS examples together.

I think a very important note here is: these examples are not maintained, published once and I cannot promise to update those but I think they still help the extension community out there to get some inspiration for their own projects.

As pictures (and source code) tell more than a thousand words you can find below the link to the video where I showcase the UI that I have build, the documentation of the CSS and the Github repo where you can find all the code:

  • Styling your Custom Frontend (Video | Github | Styleguide (html + css on git))

Now I want to give you a few examples and also explain further down a bit how I developed my custom frontend that I share.

In my use case I wanted to build a UI on top of an existing standard API from SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2 in order to purely focus in this example on a custom frontend. I chose to develop a new list view for the "Accounts" which can be embedded as a full screen mashup in the main navigation. It is not a great idea to try to re-develop a standard screen but it is a great example for showing what you can do with a custom frontend and how similar it looks and behaves. But also here, please be aware, I did not considered things like read restrictions based on org, role or territory and exactly those are the things why "re-developing" a standard list view like I did is in many cases not a good idea. I still believe it is a great example for showing the styling and building of a custom frontend.

I did build my frontend with Vue and created a very small backend with Express Node.js so that I have both as a monorepo together. I also published seperatly a styleguide so that you can use the CSS framework agnostic. 

But now let's take a look at a few screens from the application. If you want to see it in action, just take a look at the video linked above or checkout directly the source code at Github. In the video I also explain a bit more about the styling and my CSS style guide coming with the Github repository. And if you are interested in more extensibility content, you should check out my Anchor Post for my Extensibility Tutorials.

Custom Account View embedded as a full screen mashup in the standard navigation:

 Custom Account View with various elements in V2 style:

 Table Charts using the same styling and library like V2 (highcharts):

 Open Detail View, In-Iine editing and search:

 Standard quick view opens when clicking on any of the linked standard objects using custom events:

More navigation links using custom events to the standard application and form fields with V2 look:

Standard quick create of a case opening as overlay with initial parameters handed over:

Here a quick preview of the non-offical CSS styleguide shared as a simple HTML+css which you can download and launch locally:

 

I hope you enjoyed this blog article and that this helps you to build the perfect custom frontend for your individual needs!

As said initially, this is just some help from a developer for developers, I cannot provide official maintenance of those CSS styles but it may help you to build your own library that looks as close as possible like SAP Sales and Service Cloud Version 2.

Have a great day!

Jens

entry.title: Міжародна Online-лекція: Технології та інновації як рушійні сили зростання бізнесу
entry.content:
Стратегія ERP для України


Бізнес уже не може працювати «по-старому». Епоха трансформації вимагає прозорих процесів, швидких рішень і надійної основи для відбудови українських компаній. Паралельно посилюються вимоги до ефективності, управління ризиками, звітності перед банками та партнерами — і без якісних даних це перетворюється на постійну боротьбу з хаосом.​​

Саме про ці практичні виклики йтиметься на міжнародній онлайн-лекції «Переосмислення бізнесу в епоху трансформації», яку проводить Європейська Бізнес Асоціація спільно з SAP Value Advisory. Під час події говоритимемо про те, чому сучасні ERP-системи стають «нервовою системою» компанії: вони об’єднують фінанси, операції, закупівлі, логістику та звітність в єдиній системі й дають керівникам можливість працювати з узгодженими цифрами, а не з розрізненими файлами.​​

Окремий фокус — український контекст. Як ERP допомагають компаніям:​​

  • швидше закривати звітні періоди й готуватися до аудиту;

  • підвищувати прозорість для інвесторів і фондів відбудови;

  • управляти витратами та грошовими потоками в умовах нестабільності;

  • планувати масштабування в інші країни без побудови «з нуля» процесів та обліку.​​

Спікер лекції — Йожек Грушковняк, директор у команді Value Advisory компанії SAP. Він багато років працює з керівниками та власниками бізнесу в Центральній та Східній Європі, допомагаючи їм прораховувати економіку цифрових змін і впроваджувати стратегії, які спираються на реальні дані, а не припущення.​

Якщо ви будуєте стійкий бізнес, орієнтуєтеся на зростання та міжнародні партнерства і хочете навести лад у процесах та даних, приєднуйтесь до лекції й приходьте з конкретними питаннями про ваші системи, показники та наступні кроки.

До вашої уваги запис першого вебінару, а також прес-релізи на тему Пастка кастомізації: чому конкурентна перевага полягає у стандартизованому ERP-рішенні та Будуємо майбутнє України: чому професійна ERP більше не розкіш, а стратегічна необхідність.

Реєструйтеся за посиланням!

entry.title: Re: Requirement for Customer-Specific Transit Time in SAP
entry.content:
Transit times are usually defined at transportation zone / shipping condition / route level. If all customers in a country share the same transit time, you can maintain it at the country or zone level. But when one customer requires a different transit time, you need a way to override the default.

Here are the standard approaches available:

Route Determination with Customer-Specific Routes
SAP allows you to define routes based on shipping conditions, transportation zones, and sometimes customer master data. You can create a special route for the specific customer with a transit time of 56 days, while the default route remains 35 days for others. Transit time is then maintained in the route master.

Customer Master – Transportation Zone Override
In the customer master (BP → Sales Area → Shipping tab), you can assign a different transportation zone for that customer. This zone can have its own transit time (56 days), separate from the country-level zone (35 days).

Shipping Condition Differentiation
Define a unique shipping condition for the special customer. Combine it with route determination to assign a longer transit time.

Condition-Based Transit Time (Advanced ATP / Transportation Management)
If you are using SAP TM or advanced ATP, you can model transit times more flexibly with condition records. This allows customer-specific transit times without changing master data structures.

entry.title: Report:/SCMTMS/CHECK4ORPHANDODATA for orphan records in the database for dependent objects within TM
entry.content:
Report:/SCMTMS/CHECK4ORPHANDODATA for orphan records in the database for dependent objects within TM.

Overview

Following my previous blog for SAP TM Transaction WUF-Where-Used List - SAP Community  other part import after  Archiving  is consider the next steps of Orphaned data refers to records that exist in the database without corresponding references or relationships to other data, typically occurring when related records are deleted or modified in a way that breaks their connection to other data elements.

The /SCMTMS/CHECK4ORPHANDODATA report is a critical SAP Transportation Management (TM) utility designed to identify and clean up orphaned client-dependent data in the database.

This report is essential for maintaining data integrity during SAP S/4HANA conversions, upgrades, and system maintenance activities.

This report is particularly crucial during SAP S/4HANA conversion and upgrade processes

Report Parameters

 

Parameter

Description

Default Value

Notes

Client

Target client for orphan data check

Current client

Specify the client where orphan data should be identified

Test Mode

Execute in test mode without deletion

X (checked)

Recommended for initial analysis

Delete Mode

Actually, delete identified orphan data

(unchecked)

Use only after thorough testing

Object Types

Specific TM object types to check

All

Can be restricted to specific business objects

Execution Steps

  1. Navigate to Report
    • Transaction: SE38 or SE80
    • Program: /SCMTMS/CHECK4ORPHANDODATA
  2. Parameter Configuration
    • Set client parameter to target client
    • Enable test mode for initial run
    • Select specific object types if needed
    • Configure output options
  3. Execution Process
    • Execute the report in test mode first
    • Review the output for orphaned data candidates
    • Analyze the impact of potential deletions
    • Re-run in delete mode if appropriate
  4. Output Interpretation
    • Review list of orphaned objects identified
    • Check dependency relationships
    • Validate business impact before deletion

Common Issues and Solutions

Issue: Runtime Error DBSQL_STMNT_TOO_LARGE

Symptom:

  • Program terminates with runtime error DBSQL_STMNT_TOO_LARGE
  • Long execution time (many hours) before cancellation
  • Deletion of orphan data may not complete

Root Cause:

  • Large number of orphan records in database for dependent objects
  • SQL statement becomes too large for database processing

Resolution:

  1. Implement SAP Note 3701476 or relevant Support Package
  2. Consider processing data in smaller batches
  3. Review system resources and database configuration

Issue: Incomplete Orphan Data Detection

Symptom:

  • Report shows different numbers than expected
  • Inconsistent results compared to other TM reports

Root Cause:

  • Client deletion processes were interrupted or incomplete
  • Data inconsistencies at database level

Resolution:

  1. Check for abrupt/stopped client deletion status at SAP level
  2. Verify database-level orphaned client dependent data
  3. Run consistency checks before conversion activities

Output Analysis

  • Orphaned Objects: Review the list of business objects without valid parent references
  • Impact Assessment: Evaluate the business impact of removing identified orphaned data
  • Dependency Check: Ensure no active business processes depend on the identified data
  • Conversion Readiness: Confirm system readiness for S/4HANA conversion after cleanup

Related Transactions

  • SAAB: Checkpoint group activation for detailed logging
  • SE91: Message class analysis for error investigation
  • SE38: Report execution and debugging
  • SPRO: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide access

Best Practices

  • Pre-Conversion Execution: Always run this check before SAP S/4HANA conversion
  • Test Mode First: Execute in test mode before actual deletion
  • Backup Strategy: Ensure complete system backup before deletion activities
  • Scheduled Maintenance: Run during maintenance windows to avoid business disruption
  • Documentation: Document all findings and actions taken for audit purposes
  • Performance Monitoring: Monitor system performance during execution, especially for large datasets

 Refer to:

3701476 - Program /SCMTMS/CHECK4ORPHANDODATA with runtime error DBSQL_STMNT_TOO_LARGE - SAP for Me

3659947 - Check and cleanup orphan DO data - SAP for Me

3505013 - Delete step is not deleting data of dependent objects - SAP for Me

Hope this help you!

Thank you and regards.

Rogerio Lima.

entry.title: Re: Problems with the pricing condition on the SD invoice
entry.content:
Though you have indicated you have compared and same, still, check the following

  • Compare condition type ZPCI in both systems (V/06) for Condition category, origin, reference to valuation.
  • Compare pricing procedure assignment (V/08) and ensure ZPCI is set the same way in both.
  • Check copy control settings (VTFL/VTFA) for Pricing type which should allow redetermination.
  • Verify valuation integration and ensure PRD has the same valuation area settings as QA.
  • Run pricing analysis in billing document (transaction VF03 → Environment → Analysis) to see why ZPCI is being transferred instead of recalculated.

entry.title: Re: Plant in OBYC
entry.content: Direct plant assignment in OBYC is not possible. Indirect plant differentiation is possible if valuation level is set to plant. Otherwise, you need to use valuation classes or account modifiers to achieve plant‑specific G/L postings.

entry.title: Re: customer order exceeds credit limit and doesn't block...
entry.content: Yes — negative receivables do impact the credit check in SAP. They reduce the exposure, which is why your large order did not block. If this is not the desired business behavior, you’ll need to adjust credit management configuration or implement a BAdI to exclude negative receivables from the calculation. You can define which components are included in the static credit check. You can exclude credit memos or negative receivables from the exposure calculation.

entry.title: Maintenance operation status is changed back to "In Preparation" when assigning a user
entry.content:
Hi SAP Experts,

Can you please help me with the following behavior in SAP S/4HANA Public cloud, maintenance processes?

I have a maintenace order with type YA02 --> proactive maintenance order which is created via maintenance plan.
I release the order and then  I use the app "Perform Maintenace Jobs" and assign the operation to my user. Then, the operation is removed from the list.
I've found out that this happens, because the staus of the operation is changed back to "In Preparation" and the operation is not DSPT anymore. For YA01 orders, it works perfectly: The operation stays in the list and I can start working (create a confirmation)

Steps to Reproduce 

  1. Open Maintenance Order (YA02)
  2. Release the order
  3. Additonal Functions: Dispatch Operations
  4. Save and "read only"
    --> Status of all operations: REL DSPT and Subphase = Ready for Execution
  5. Open App "Perform Maintenance Jobs" and search for the order
  6. Select the first operation
  7. Click on "Assign to me" 
    --> operation is not visible in the app anymore
  8. Open Maintenance Order
    --> Status of first operation: REL and Subphase = In Preparation

BR
Simon

entry.title: Call for Speakers – SAP Inside Track NRW
entry.content:
Call for Speakers – SAP Inside Track NRW

After several years without a regional SAP Inside Track in our area, it’s time to bring the community back together. Therefore We are excited to announce SAP Inside Track NRW 2026 — and we’re now opening the Call for Speakers. Some of you may remember the legendary sitPOTT from 7 years ago. Those events showed how strong, curious, and hands‑on the SAP community in NRW can be. We want to build on that spirit: informal, practical, and full of real project experience.

 

What we’re looking for

We welcome contributions from across the SAP universe, including but not limited to:

  • SAP BTP, CAP, UI5, ABAP, Integration Suite
  • Analytics, Data & AI, Security, Cloud Operations
  • Project insights, architecture decisions, lessons learned
  • Demos, prototypes, experiments, or “this is what we tried and how it went” stories

Whether you have spoken at many events or this would be your first time on stage if you have something worth sharing, we’d love to hear from you.

 

Session format

  • Duration: 30–40 minutes or 15-20 Minutes.
  • Format: Presentation, live demo, interactive session — whatever fits your topic
  • Language: English

 

Event details

  • Event: SAP Inside Track NRW
  • Date: 13. Juni 2026
  • Location: On-Site Adesso Dortmund

 

How to submit your session

Please utilize the following Microsoft Form to submit a Topic Call for Speakers: SAP Inside Track NRW.

entry.title: SAP Inside Track NRW
entry.content:
We’re bringing a regional SAP Inside Track back to NRW, and we’d love to see you there. After the memorable sitPOTT from soon to be 7 years ago, it’s time to revive that spirit of learning, networking, and hands on exchange. SAP Inside Track NRW will be a day shaped by the community: practical sessions, real project insights, and plenty of opportunities to connect with people who work with SAP technologies every day.

 

What to expect

  • A full day of sessions from community speakers
  • Topics across SAP BTP, ABAP, UI5, Integration, Analytics, Security, and more
  • Space for discussions, questions, and sharing your own experiences
  • A relaxed atmosphere — no suits required
  • Networking with familiar faces and new ones

 

Event details

  • Event: SAP Inside Track NRW
  • Date: June 13, 2026
  • Location: On-Site Adesso Dortmund
  • Registration: Will be opened soon
  • Admission: free

 

Who should join

Whether you’re deep into SAP or just curious about what’s happening in the ecosystem, you’re welcome:

  • Developers
  • Architects
  • Consultants
  • Students
  • Tech enthusiasts
  • Community veterans (including those who still remember sitPott)

 

Why attend

SAP Inside Tracks are built by the community, for the community. They’re not polished marketing events. They’re places where people speak openly about what works, what doesn’t, and what they’ve learned along the way. If you enjoy practical insights more than glossy slides, you’ll feel right at home.

Here’s what makes attending worthwhile:

  • Practical experience instead of theory Speakers talk about what they’ve actually built, broken, fixed, or learned along the way. No slideware, no buzzwords - just real insights you can take back to work the very next day.
  • Learning beyond your own SAP bubble Whether your focus is BTP, ABAP, UI5, Integration, Analytics, or Security, the sessions are designed to widen your view and connect the dots between disciplines.
  • Open exchange with experts and peers Ask questions, challenge ideas, and get honest answers from people who deal with the same problems you do.

entry.title: Integration Suite API Management CF custom domain activation via self-service
entry.content:
Introduction

In this blog post you will learn how to setup and activate custom domains (standard setup not mTLS) for SAP Integration Suite API management runtime based on Cloud Foundry via de self-service procedure. If you already have a custom domain activate and in the past this was performed by SAP, this is the blog for you. 

To keep this blog to the point the focus is to provide detailed steps and information for this case. Information about obtaining a certificate, create a virtual host for API Management or updating DNS records are only briefly touched.

Prerequisites

To follow the steps explained please make sure you have or gathered:

  • Administrator access to the subaccount in which Integration Suite is running. To be able to:
    • Provide required authorizations
    • Create/Update service keys
  • SAP Integration Suite, API management is setup and running. Launchpad is accessible.
  • SAP API management a test API is published and working with the standard SAP domain.
  • DNS administrator authorization or a contact within the organization authorized to perform the required activity.
  • Certificate administrator authorization or a contact within the organization authorized to perform the required activity.
  • A HTTP Client like Postman for executing API calls.
    • Access to api.sap.com for details on the required API actions

API Management Service key

Before we are able to call any APIs for information and activities with API management it is important a service key is created with specific authorizations: APIManagement.SelfService.Administrator using the plan apiportal-apiaccess. To create an instance you need to navigate towards: Home page Global account->subaccount for integration suite->left hand menu Services->Instances and subscriptions->create instance with the following details, using the correct Space:

As a result the output should look like below:

This service key is required for all upcoming activities to validate existing virtual hosts and create/update a virtual host for custom domain usage.

APIM virtual host overview

Assumption is the service key is created and active. As a first step try to retrieve a token for the service key, my examples are from Postman:

As noticed you can here also validate when the response is positive the authorization is properly linked.

After this step is completed you can call the endpoint:

  • {hostname from servicekey URL}/apiportal/operations/1.0/Configuration.svc/VirtualHostRequests

with the hostname from the service key, with the HTTP GET method this should result in the overview of virtual hosts for the API Management instance. If you currently only have the SAP standard domain this is the only record to be returned.

APIM create virtual host (optional)

This step is optional and only required if not additional virtual host is already created

A virtual host for APIM can easily be created calling the endpoint: 

  • {hostname from servicekey URL}/apiportal/operations/1.0/Configuration.svc/VirtualHostRequests including the body as:
{
    "accountId": "{accountId}",
    "virtualHostUrl": "{desired virtual host prefix}",
    "isDefaultVirtualHostRequest": false,
    "operation": "CREATE"
}
To be sure the virtual host is created it should result in a positive response and it should become visible in APIM within the API proxy section, as example below:

APIM read virtual hosts - available

Retrieving all virtual hosts for an APIM instance is handled via the same URL mentioned a couple of times in this blog: 

  • {hostname from servicekey URL}/apiportal/operations/1.0/Configuration.svc/VirtualHostRequests 

a response looks like:

Important fields are highlighted which are required to create/update a custom domain for the created virtual host.

APIM create keystore for custom domain

Compared to SAP Cloud Integration custom domain which is handled via de Custom Domain Manager UI for APIM this is not working in the same concept. This also means the required certificate needs to be created differently and more information is required. For APIM a certificate needs to be bought/requested from the used CA within the company without using an CSR from SAP.  In this blog we are using a wildcard certificate which is used for all APIM environments.

The certificate details you need to create a keystore are:

  • private key 
  • public key
  • certificate chain including root and intermediate certificates

Important is that the certificate needs to be in a .pem format. In our case we already get the certificates delivered in .pem format. It is important the the public key part including the certificate chain is created in the following order in which the first entry is at the top: 

  1. public key client certificate
  2. intermediate certificates (if any is available)
  3. root CA

And saved as a .pem file. The exact steps to create the keystore including the required content is described in SAP documentation: https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/manage-certificates . To create a JAR file we used the JAVA JDK as a download (not required to install) in combination with PowerShell:

In PowerShell the following commmands are used:

  • Create JAR keystore: {location java JDK}\bin\jar -cf customdomain.jar main.pem privateKey.pem
  • Update JAR keystore with META-INF information: {location java JDK}\bin\jar -uf customdomain.jar META-INF/descriptor.properties

When the creation is successful this keystore needs to be uploaded.

APIM upload keystore for custom domain

The upload step is very simple. Navigate within SAP Integration Suite overview page towards: Left hand menu Configure->APIs->Tab: Certificates :

and click the create button with the following setup:

Important is to select Key Store and New Store. The Store Name and Name value can be anything you like within the boundaries of what SAP allows and in the upload field you need to select the created JAR file. If you select update it will give a warning the create is the approach. In case you select update and you upload a new certificate the already existing one is overwritten with the same name.

If the upload is going as expected it will be listed in the tab Certificates.

APIM activate custom domain

If all previous steps are completed successfully, activation can start. Be aware of the following:

  • The used root CA for custom domain needs to be trusted by applications/systems to be able to make a working connection.
  • Make a decision if the custom domain needs to be the default domain when creating or importing an API proxy. We decided not to use the custom domain as default virtual host.
  • After custom domain activation you need to
    • update any existing DNS CNAME records. The target URL will change. However this URL will only be available after the activation is executed via an API call. This target value can be located in field lbHost in the response from the activation when this is positive.
    • redeploy all API proxies using the custom domain and as a second step all API products. This to make sure the correct certificate is used. This is especially important when the custom domain is already used and the certificate chain is changed.

Activation for custom domain is handled via an API call:

  • {hostname from servicekey URL}/apiportal/operations/1.0/Configuration.svc/VirtualHostRequests

With the following content:

{
    "accountId" : "{accountId from read operation}",  
    "virtualHostUrl": "{full custom domain with virtual host prefix}",
    "isDefaultVirtualHostRequest" : false,
    "isForCustomDomain": true,
    "keyStoreName": "{created during keystore upload}",
    "keyStoreAlias": "{created during keystore upload}",
    "operation" : "UPDATE",
    "virtualHostId":"{virtualHostId from read operation}"
}
A positive response should look like:

The values in fields virtualHostUrl and lbHost are important for updating the CNAME record in DNS. 

APIM create/update custom domain DNS CNAME

To make sure the custom domain can be reached and is forwarded to the correct endpoint a DNS CNAME record is required for every APIM virtual host activated for custom domain. In our case we already had a CNAME record for our custom domain pointing to the standard SAP domain [

test.apimanagement.eu20.hana.ondemand.com] as provided by SAP when they initially handled the custom domain activities for APIM.  As mentioned in the previous paragraph the CNAME now needs to be:
  • virtualHostUrl value -> lbHost value

Be aware in case you use multiple virtual host in an APIM environment the lbHost value might be the same but this is not causing any issues related to call the correct endpoints.

After it is validated via DNS checkers the CNAME record is updated the first step is to activate 1 API proxy and the linked API product and validate the correct routing and certificates are handled. We decided to edit the API proxy and perform a dummy change and updated the revision with details about the redeployment. Other options are also available.

In our case we used temporary a testing endpoint specific for the custom domain validation. We also provided this endpoint to application, system and partner contacts for validation purposes and to request them to validate if the root CA is available in the trust store.

Conclusion

The switch from SAP managed custom domains for our organization towards self-service is a logical one. We got confronted with the self-service approach 5 working days prior to the current certificate expiring which gave us clear time contraints. Luckily the creation of the virtual host and retrieval of the overview of virtual hosts was already known for us and the service key already existed.

Looking at the SAP documentation most steps are stated (high-level) in multiple pages however from our perspective some pieces of documentation raised questions from our end. With a ticket towards SAP we received definitive clarification to get this change done correctly without any disruptions. This is the reason the blog was written.

Hopefully this blog is giving others the insights and information required to make this working properly within the own organization.

Documentation & Links

If you like to read more information about custom domains and the setup it requires for other cases I can recommend reading the below helpful information:

  • Request or update an APIM custom domain: https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-api-management/sap-api-management/requesting-for-custom-domain-for-virtual-host 
  • Create a JAR keystore: https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/manage-certificates
  • Configure DNS for a custom domain: https://help.sap.com/docs/custom-domain/custom-domain-service/configure-dns-for-custom-domain

the recycle bin is turned off since Oracle 10g because it was causing a lot of issues especially using BW.  The decision has been made after throughout analysis and the collected experiences.

entry.title: Re: Issue with shipping point during Return To Vendor
entry.content:
Why the error occurs is because, in SPRO → Enterprise Structure → Assignment → Logistics Execution → Shipping → Assign shipping data to plant, you can only assign one sales area per plant. When you create a return order, the system looks at Plant (from item), Shipping conditions (from sales area/customer master) & Loading group (from material master). Since the plant VP01 is tied to sales area VS01/10/00 in customizing, the system tries to fetch shipping conditions from that sales area, even though your BP is only extended to VS01/20/00 and the result is shipping point determination fails.

You don’t need custom logic; there are standard ways to handle this:

Assign Plant to Multiple Sales Areas via Common Distribution Channel/Division
SAP allows you to define common distribution channels and divisions. If you set up VS01/10/00 and VS01/20/00 to share a common distribution channel/division, the plant assignment can be reused across both. This way, shipping point determination works for both sales areas without changing SPRO each time.

Use Customer Master Shipping Conditions
Maintain the correct shipping condition in the export customer master (BP → Sales Area → Shipping tab). The system will then use that shipping condition in combination with plant + loading group to determine the shipping point, even if the plant is linked to another sales area.

entry.title: Re: In MTO, Sequent ion of Material Production is not wel...
entry.content:
Your FG has multiple possible production paths depending on raw material quality. Standard BOM explosion in MRP will create planned orders for all SFG levels defined in the BOM. In reality, only certain operations (e.g. Grinding + Packing, or Annealing + Grinding + Packing) are required. The challenge is: how to tell the system to skip unnecessary planned orders and consume raw material directly at the correct stage.

Standard SAP Approaches

1. Alternative BOMs
Maintain multiple BOMs for the FG. BOM 1 → Grinding + Packing and BOM 2 → Annealing + Grinding + Packing. At order creation, select the correct BOM based on raw material quality. MRP will then only generate planned orders for the chosen path.

Advantage: clean separation of production paths.
Limitation: requires manual or rule‑based BOM selection.

2. Production Versions
Link each BOM + Routing combination to a Production Version. Example PV1 → BOM with Grinding + Packing. PV2 → BOM with Annealing + Grinding + Packing. MRP uses the production version to determine which operations/components are relevant. You can control which production version is valid by lot size, validity dates, or business rules.

Advantage: standard, flexible, widely used in MTO scenarios.

3. Phantom Assemblies (Special Procurement Key 50)
Model intermediate SFGs (Drawing, Annealing, Grinding) as phantom assemblies. Phantom assemblies explode in the BOM but do not generate separate planned orders. Raw material consumption can then be directly pegged to the FG or the required operation.

Advantage: avoids unnecessary planned orders.
Limitation: use only if SFG stock is not managed separately.

4. Engineering Workbench / Variant Configuration (Advanced)
If the choice of path depends on raw material characteristics, you can use variant configuration or classification to select the right BOM/routing dynamically. This is more advanced but allows the system to “decide” automatically which operations are required.

Having said that, the recommended approach would be

  • Use Production Versions with alternative BOMs/routings.
  • Model optional SFGs as phantom assemblies if you don’t want separate orders.
  • At order creation, select the correct production version based on raw material quality.
  • This ensures MRP generates only the required planned orders and consumption is posted correctly.

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud Certification (C_BCBDC): The Ultimate Guide to Passing SAP’s New AI Scenario
entry.content:
Introduction

Certification is changing, and it is a good thing. Instead of cramming facts and guessing at multiple choice, you are invited to think like you do on the job. You will work through real scenarios, connect the dots, and show how you deliver outcomes. In this post we will talk about what is new, and how to prepare for SAP BDC (C_BCBDC) certification.

Understanding the New BDC Certification Format - Scenario Based

You will interact with an AI avatar to respond to real customer or project situations. For learners who prefer not to use AI there is an alternative option to upload a video for human review. Link for more details : SAP Certification is Changing What You Need to Know about the New Format, Reimagining Certification

Preparation

SAP BDC Learning Journey

For the best chance of success, complete the full SAP Business Data Cloud learning journey from start to finish. Treat every module, hands on exercise, and quiz as required to build real exam readiness. Give special attention to the core topics below

Core Topics in SAP Business Data Cloud

1. BDC

  • One domain model
  • SAP 4 Me
  • Formations
  • Intelligent Applications
  • Data Products
  • Data Security
  • Architecture
  • BDC Cockpit
  • Zero copy
  • ORD / CSN
  • Data Lake

2. SAP Datasphere Integration

  • BDC-generated spaces
  • Harmonization through modeling
  • Semantic enrichment
  • Extending SAP-delivered models
  • Installing data products to a space

3. SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

  • Role of SAC in BDC
  • Extending and discovering intelligent applications
  • Use cases for intelligent applications

4. BW Modernization

  • Lift, shift, and innovate strategies
  • Data Product Generator
  • Subscriptions and versions
  • Why BW is included in BDC

5. SAP Databricks Integration

  • ML Flow, delta share, notebooks, Unity Catalog
  • Exploratory Data Analysis
  • Industry use cases
  • Sharing data products and ML results between Databricks and BDC

Sample Scenarios to Understand the Exam Format

Scenario 1: Global Manufacturing Company – Unified Analytics & Governance

Context: A global manufacturing company operates across Europe and Asia. They run SAP S/4HANA, legacy SAP BW, and several non-SAP systems for logistics and procurement. Leadership wants a single, governed analytics platform with reusable data products and ready-made insights.

Question: How does BDC help

Scenario 2: Financial Services Firm – AI-Driven Risk & Compliance Reporting

Context: A financial services firm needs real-time risk reporting, strict compliance, and AI-driven forecasting. They must integrate SAP finance data with external market feeds and apply advanced analytics.

Question: How can Financial Services Firm integrate third-party data with its SAP data using SAP Business Data Cloud?

Exam Questions Breakdown from My Attempt

Based on my recent experience, here’s how the exam questions were distributed:

  • Technical Knowledge of BDC: 40%
  • Integration with SAP Business Warehouse: 15%
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Analytics Cloud: 15%
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Datasphere: 15%
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Databricks: 15%

Helpful Links

  1. Exploring SAP Business Data Cloud Learning Journey
  2. SAP Certification is Changing What You Need to Know about the New Format
  3. Reimagining Certification
  4. SAP Certified Associate SAP Business Data Cloud

entry.title: Re: Returns to Vendor process using Advanced Returns Mana...
entry.content:
Hi @AAkash1 ,

In SAP S/4HANA Advanced Returns Management, you create a Return Purchase Order directly with reference to the original PO using the returns functionality (not a standard ME21N transaction). The system links the new Return PO to the original PO, so yes—you can track the original purchase order from the newly created return document.

Steps in Vendor Returns with Advanced Returns Management
Purchase Order creation → Standard PO created in ME21N.
Inbound delivery → Goods receipt posted against the PO.
Inspection/decision → If goods are defective or need to be returned, initiate Advanced Returns Management.

Use Advanced Returns Management to create the Return PO with reference to the original PO. The system automatically links them, so you can track the original purchase order from the return document. ME21N alone won’t give you the full integration benefits.

  • Check Maintenance Plan Settings, : Review the maintenance plan settings to understand how new orders are created and released.
  • Review Order Release Process: Ensure that the order release process does not include steps that reset the operation status.
  • Verify App Configuration: Check the configuration of the "Perform Maintenance Jobs" app to ensure it handles operation status correctly.
  • System Logs: Review system logs for any errors or warnings related to maintenance orders.
  • Customizing Settings: Check the customizing settings related to maintenance orders and plans.
  • User Permissions:

entry.title: Re: Storing of documents in database table
entry.content: In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, storing uploaded files as BLOB/RAWSTRING in custom tables is not considered best practice, even temporarily, due to database, performance, and governance implications. The recommended approach as I know is to create a lightweight request or draft business object early and link attachments via the standard Attachments API to this object, then proceed with the final object upon approval.

entry.title: Re: Issue with SAP BAS Project Creation: "No Database Ava...
entry.content: In SAP BTP trial accounts, this error usually occurs when the SAP HANA Cloud instance is not fully provisioned, not running, or not available in the same space where the BAS project is being created. Please ensure that the HANA Cloud instance is created and active in the dev space, and that it is visible for HDI container creation during project setup. If the problem persists in a trial environment, it is often caused by trial resource limitations or delayed service availability, in which case re-creating the instance or using a different space typically resolves the issue.

entry.title: PP-WM batch determination
entry.content:
Hi,

There is existing system with PP-WM integration.

I execute the following process - production order confirmation in CO11N. When click "Goods movements" it brings me to the screen with components. And I see that batches are already assigned.

My problem is that I can not find the reason, why they were assigned and according to which logic.

What I found is:

1.

- Batch search procedure exists here:

Logistics - General >>Batch Management>>Batch Determination and Batch Check>>Batch Search Procedure Definition>> Define Inventory Management Search Procedure

- Batch search procedure is assigned to movement type 261: 

Logistics - General >>Batch Management>>Batch Determination and Batch Check>>Batch Search Procedure Allocation and Check Activation>>Allocate IM Search Procedure/Activate Check

But there are no any Batch strategies in MBC1 at all, so looks like the Batch search procedure is not in use.

--------------------------------------------

2.

- Also there are no any assigned WM Batch search procedure: 

Logistics - General >>Batch Management>>Batch Determination and Batch Check>>Batch Search Procedure Allocation and Check Activation>>Allocate IM Search Procedure/Activate Check

So it looks like is also not in use.

-------------------------------------------

3. I checked implementation of BADIs and user exits. So there are no any implementations here: 

WORKORDER_CONFIRM
WORKORDER_GOODSMVT

EXIT_SAPLCORF_101
EXIT_SAPLCORF_102
EXIT_SAPLCORF_103
EXIT_SAPLCORF_104
EXIT_SAPLCORF_105
EXIT_SAPLCORF_106

-----------------------------------------------------

4. In debug mode I found that batches are selected from table LQUA using parameters like Material, Storage location etc. But no any batch determination procedure is used.

----------------------------------------------------

The question is: are the any ways where Batch determination can be set up for my case? Any other user exits. Maybe there is some specific of PP-WM integration?

entry.title: Re: Recently SAP HANA tenant is dropping connections afte...
entry.content: In SAP HANA multi-tenant scale-out environments, connection drops or refusals via an intermediary tenant are commonly related to resource pressure, service instability, or network issues on that tenant. Please check indexserver stability, resource utilization, and inter-node connectivity on AH2; if no clear cause is found, opening an SAP incident with full system information is recommended.

entry.title: Re: Minimum grants required for m_expensive_statement_trace
entry.content: In SAP HANA, access to SYS.M_EXPENSIVE_STATEMENTS requires monitoring privileges and cannot be granted in full isolation. Restricting a user to only HANA Studio/SQL Console while blocking Cockpit or other clients is not supported via HANA authorization; such restrictions must be enforced outside the database (e.g. network or tool level).
